name: Recurrent Furunculosis
summary: This document outlines decolonization strategies to prevent recurrent furunculosis (abscesses, boils) caused by Staphylococcus aureus in otherwise healthy individuals. It details primary and alternative treatment regimens, along with important clinical considerations and comments on the current state of treatment.
description: The document focuses on preventing recurrent Staphylococcus aureus infections. It emphasizes the need for culturing multiple sites to accurately identify colonization. Various decolonization protocols are presented, including combined chlorhexidine and mupirocin regimens, as well as bleach baths. The document also notes the lack of a "gold standard" treatment and the high rates of recolonization.

syndromes.name: Recurrent Furunculosis
syndromes.description: A condition characterized by repeated episodes of furuncles (boils) or abscesses.

special_considerations: Need to culture multiple sites (nose, throat, inguinal area) for accurate detection of S. aureus colonization, as nares-only cultures can miss up to half of colonized individuals.
No "gold standard" regimen for decolonization currently exists, and the optimal regimen and duration of treatment are uncertain.
Rates of recolonization and recurrent infections remain high even after decolonization treatment.

pathogens.name: Staphylococcus aureus
pathogens.summary: The causative agent of furunculosis. Both Methicillin-Susceptible (MSSA) and Methicillin-Resistant (MRSA) strains are implicated.
